column4: hi there! cna anyone tell me what's going on when you see a usb as /dev/sdc rather than /dev/sdc1 or whatever?
I would like to partition such a usb but I'm not sure how
Thats not possible. What might causes that, is, that a fileesystem was created on the entire device instead on a partition.
/dev/sdc is the USB device, and /dev/sdc1 is a partition on that device.
that's what normally happens but sometimes a usb partition appears as /dev/sdc
would I be safe in repartitioning it then, even though fdisk says it's not a valid partition table?
Actually, it doesnt matter :)
at the mo it's exactly as the factory sent ti.
And whatsthe problem with it? :)
awesome, I'll give it a shot. I was just worried that there was something deaper going on that I didn't understand.
like the disk had some kind of hiden partition table
There is no such hidden thing ;)
gparted slightly freaked me out by refusing to put more than one partition on it.
You could use fdisk as well.
yes I will. I normally od but I want to copy and enlarge partitions from another usb stick that I have ubuntu installed on
I'll setup the new partitions with fdsik then try gparted again to see if it will play
Why dont you just create the partitions like you want them, and copy over the content of the other usb stick, instead messing with fdisk AND gparted?
I'd like uuids to be preserved as well if possible
You can set the UUIDs afterwards using tune2fs e.g.
ok might give it a shot, what would th copy command be cp -Rp * ?
Ok thanks, that appears to have worked, I just partitioned with fdisk after wiping the partition table with dd to be sure and copied the partitions across with gparted. Just off to test it, bye
